statement.text: In situ bypass leaves the great saphenous vein in its anatomic bed, lysing the valves with a valvulotome to allow antegrade arterial flow, avoiding the handling injury and size mismatch of reversed vein bypass.

explanation.intuition: Instead of removing and flipping the vein (which damages it and causes size mismatch), the in situ technique leaves the vein where it is and just destroys the internal valves. This way, the big end stays at the groin and the small end goes to the small target artery.
explanation.key_insight: In situ bypass provides optimal size matching (larger proximal vein to larger femoral, smaller distal vein to smaller tibial). The key technical steps are complete valve lysis and ligating all side branches (AVF source if missed).
explanation.technical_details: Technique: expose proximal and distal ends, ligate and divide tributaries, lyse valves with Hall or LeMaitre valvulotome (flexible or rigid), confirm complete lysis with flow probe or angiography. Tributaries: must be ligated to prevent AV fistula. Completeness assessment: angioscopy, continuous-wave Doppler, intraoperative angiography. Advantages: size match, minimal handling. Disadvantages: residual AV fistulas (5-10%), requires surveillance.

procedural_details.technique: Leave vein in bed, lyse valves, ligate tributaries
procedural_details.valve_lysis: Hall or LeMaitre valvulotome (flexible or rigid)
procedural_details.tributary_management: Must ligate all to prevent AV fistula
procedural_details.complications: Residual AV fistula 5-10% (requires post-op surveillance and ligation)

clinical_pearls: In situ provides optimal proximal-to-distal size matching
Must ligate all tributaries to prevent AV fistula
Surveillance required to detect and ligate residual AVFs
